newScannedThrough: Tech Trends 2026 report (17th annual, released January 2026)

newContent.title: Tech Trends 2026: The Great Rebuild - Architecting an AI-Native Tech Organization
keyFindings: AI Architects expected to nearly double from 30% to 58% of tech teams within two years
New roles: Human-AI Collaboration Designers, Edge AI Engineers, Forward-Deployed Engineers
57% report shifting from project-based to product-centric operating models
Nearly 70% of tech leaders plan to grow teams in response to generative AI
Two-thirds piloting or deploying AI agents as team members
CIO role expanding - 70% serving as enterprise-wide AI evangelists
Governance shifting to adaptive 'three M's': map, measure, monitor in real-time

newContent.title: Tech Trends 2026 Press Release: AI Comes of Age
keyFindings: Only 11% have AI agents in production despite 38% piloting - major pilot-to-production gap
Organizations trying to automate human-designed processes rather than redesigning for AI-first
Building hybrid human-digital workforces requiring new HR-equivalent frameworks
IT function shifting from service delivery to strategic leadership
Infrastructure crisis: usage growth outpacing cost reductions

newContent.title: TMT Predictions 2026: The AI Gap Narrows
keyFindings: Autonomous AI agent market projected to reach $8.5B by 2026, $35B by 2030
75% of companies may invest in agentic AI by end of 2026
Inference-optimized chip market growing to $50B in 2026
Industrial robot installed base to surpass 5.5 million by 2026

organizationalFindings.evidence: Only 11% of organizations have AI agents in production despite 38% piloting them
organizationalFindings.implication: Scaling barrier is organizational/operational, not technical
organizationalFindings.specimenRelevance: Cross-cutting - relevant to all specimens piloting agentic AI

organizationalFindings.evidence: Expected to nearly double from 30% to 58% of tech teams within two years
organizationalFindings.implication: New structural role becoming standard in tech orgs
organizationalFindings.specimenRelevance: Creates new specimen signal to track

organizationalFindings.evidence: 57% report shifting from project-based to product-centric operating models
organizationalFindings.implication: Structural reorganization toward value streams, not project offices
organizationalFindings.specimenRelevance: Validates 'Dedicated AI Unit' model with product focus

organizationalFindings.evidence: Two-thirds piloting/deploying AI agents as team members; new roles like Human-AI Collaboration Designers
organizationalFindings.implication: Hybrid workforce is structural reality, not future speculation

organizationalFindings.evidence: 70% of CIOs serving as enterprise-wide AI evangelists; almost a third say orchestrating peer tech leaders is essential
organizationalFindings.implication: Tech leadership expanding scope from delivery to transformation
organizationalFindings.specimenRelevance: Validates 'Chief AI Officer' variations and CIO evolution patterns

organizationalFindings.evidence: Moving from point-in-time reviews to adaptive 'map, measure, monitor' continuous oversight
organizationalFindings.implication: Traditional governance cycles too slow for AI pace
organizationalFindings.specimenRelevance: Relevant to 'AI Council' and 'Governance Board' patterns

summary: First scan of Deloitte Tech Trends. The 2026 report (17th annual) contains rich organizational findings: only 11% have agents in production vs 38% piloting (major execution gap), AI Architect roles nearly doubling, 57% shifting to product-centric models, two-thirds deploying agents as team members, and CIOs expanding to enterprise AI evangelists. High relevance for structural research - multiple mechanism confirmations and new role patterns to track.
recommendedActions: Add 'AI Architect' as tracked role in specimen structural layers
Update mechanism evidence for 'Agent Workforce Integration' with Deloitte survey data
Create research queue item for 'pilot-to-production gap' as analytical theme
Add Deloitte Tech Trends to annual refresh calendar (January releases)
